name: A ca. 1925 letter from the stage act Tolliver & Harris regarding a scheduling problem attributed to legendary blues singer Bessie Smith.

citation.text: Courtesy of Middle Georgia Archives via Digital Library of Georgia.
Tolliver & Harris, “Letter: to Charles Henry Douglass, Jr., Macon, Georgia, possibly 1925,” Digital Public Library of America, https://dp.la/item/0ae406469f1ac62d31d6c5f86b0ab197.

text:
Transcription:

Jac[damage] 

Ju[damage] 



Mr Douglas

Mgr [Manager] Douglas Theatre

Macon Ga. [Georgia] 

Dear Sir.

We want to inform you why we are not playing your house this week with the Bessie Smith unit. Last tuesday she aggreed [agreed] to pay our Railroad fare there but at the last minute she refused to do so rather than pay it from the [deleted text: sallm] small salary we were geting [getting] we closed. Now we dont know what she may tell you so we want to be square and that is why we are writeing[writing] you. We will no dout [doubt] pick up your house next week as Mr Revene picks us up at once. As for the reports on the act you may ask Radcliff or Allen & Stokes we have two a no. [number] 1. acts. Hopeing [Hoping] to play you in the near future

We beg to remain 

Yours truly 

[Signed] Tolliver & Harris

isRelatedTo.name: A 1925 photograph of Gertrude “Ma” Rainey, known as the "Mother of the Blues," one of the most influential early female blues singers.
A 1929 Douglas Theatre handbill for Bessie Smith’s “all-talking” film.
Ukulele sheet music for “The Saint Louis Blues,” written by W.C. Handy, 1914.
The sheet music for “The Crazy Blues,” performed by Mamie Smith, 1920.

A 2010 interview with Guthrie Ramsey and Steve Almond in which they describe the history and demise of the blues.
The album cover of Blues for Rampart Street, recorded by Ida Cox and Coleman Hawkins at Radio City Music Hall in New York City in 1961.
A photograph of the rhythm-and-blues group Gladys Knight and the Pips receiving a proclamation honoring the group in 1970.
A photograph from 1990 of contemporary rhythm-and-blues singer Toni Braxton, who rose to fame in the 1990s.
An encyclopedic overview of blues music, including primary sources and discussion of the origin, development, and impact of blues.
A map of the migration of blues music and styles across the United States.
